msItem.title: Fistula in ano
msItem.author: John of Arderne
msItem.incipit: 1r wele herted and riy3te wele suffre scharpe medicynes and if he were of good complexioun
msItem.explicit: 25v at onys inne warme white wyn
msItem.note: The text begins imperfectly and features spaces left blank for medical illustrations that are referred to in the text but were never executed.

msItem.title: Somnia Danielis
msItem.rubric: 26r Here begynnep þe Interpretacioun of Danyell þe prophete to hym schewed in Baboloyne by pe holy gooste of mannes dremes in slepynge
msItem.incipit: 26r Aues A man þat birdes fiȝt with hym it bitokeneþ wreþe
msItem.note: The text is imperfect because the lower of half of f. 30 has been cut out.

msItem.title: Treatise on prognosis of diseases and their treatment [translation of De prognosticis]
msItem.author: Bernard de Gordon
msItem.incipit: 31r Age is moder of for[g]etilhed and for as meche as þe science of pronosticacioun or of tellynge a fore
msItem.explicit: 32v and whan it is lenk be his fete kneis leggis and armes necke and face wasshene

msItem.title: Verse prophecy about the realm of England
msItem.incipit: 34r When bandeges be bruers and brew bere and aylle / and bathelders be bakers and bake in a male / when charing Crosse spotes wele in a hane [?] goun / Thene shall pride and Enuey out of England \fast/ ren / When londen brygde [crossed out: and waltam] and waltame crosse makethe a grette fraye
msItem.note: Added by an (?) early 16th-century hand. Full transcription. Not recorded in the (Digital) Index of Middle English Verse.

msItem.title: Table of Contents for Gilbertus Anglicus, Compendium medicinae
msItem.rubric: 34v This is þe calandre of this booke where in is wretyn certeyne Chapitres of Surgerie for helye of man and wommans bodies as it appereþ more plenlier bi þes Chapiteles here after folowynge
msItem.incipit: 34v The first chapitre of þis booke is Scotomye - Capitulo .1.
msItem.note: The table of contents includes 4 additional chapters (Chapters 76-79).

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.note: This wisdom is also cited as a model for a good physician by John Arderne in his Fistula in ano.

msItem.title: Compendium medicinae [Middle English translation]
msItem.author: Gilbertus Anglicus
msItem.incipit: 36r Scotomye is suche a sekenes of the Brayne that maketh a man to seme that he seche flyes oþer blak thingis in þe Eyre
msItem.explicit: 128v eiþer wiþ fresshe butter eiþer wiþ larde imedled wiþ butter eiþer wiþe oile of whete eiþer wiþ þe white of an egge et cetera
msItem.note: The text ends imperfectly at the end due to missing leaves.

msItem.title: Two medical recipe for a short breath
msItem.incipit: 84v Jhesus for short wynd and for the lyuer take wort and wyld tyme and styll them to geder / Item tak bay[e]s and the leves of bayes and boyll them or styll them in whyt wyne
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand. Full transcription.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.incipit: 104v Rosmari violetes . hertes tonge boil them in condit water to the half Then take erthnotes and blanch a dosyn of theme and bet thm and with the forsaid licour mak almond mylke
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand. Full transcription.

msItem.title: Chapter on infertility
msItem.incipit: 122r Concepcion id est þe conseyuyng is lettyd nowe be vice of þe man and nowe be vice of þe woman as is of retencion of þe menstrue and of to miche flowinge of þe menstrue and of drynesse because of fa\i/llynge of the matriment or fedinge and oftentyme of an moisthede the whiche stoppeþe the mouþe of the moder and of sledr spereme
msItem.explicit: 123r and soche oþere and make him hote stiwinge and hote anoyntynge if it come of vice of þe [y]erde it is incurable
msItem.note: Treated as chapter 76 in the Compendium medicinae.

msItem.title: Chapter on leprosy
msItem.rubric: 123r Of þe lepre and þe cure
msItem.incipit: 123r Lepra is a corrupcioun of þe membris commyng of putrifaccion or rottyng of hit abid lepra is caused of melious mete as is þe lyouns fleysh hors flesh assen flesh and siche oþere of coleric mete
msItem.explicit: 125r and þan set þat iren vpon and htoe iren and presse him togider and wiþ that oil that cometh þereof anoynte the place
msItem.note: Incorporated as a chapter in the Compendium medicinae, but not listed or numbered in the table of contents

msItem.title: Chapter on hoarseness
msItem.incipit: 125r Raucedo id est horsed or þe impediment or hindrynge of þe voce is caudis of dyuerse causes but principali of þese causes of moisthed and drynesse and of the defaute of þe spirites and of the vertues of drynesse it is caused in 2 maneres or of þe drynes þe whiche werkeþ vnevenhed
msItem.explicit: 126r if this passioun cume of defaute of þe spiritis þan helpe the pacient with restorynge and of ortatife medicyn as is seid in þe etik ffe et cetera
msItem.note: Treated as chapter 77 of the Compendium medicinae.

msItem.title: The Sekenesse of Women
msItem.author: Gilbertus Anglicus
msItem.rubric: Sores and greuance þat women haue
msItem.incipit: 126r Soris we shull vnderstond that women han lesse hete þan men in her body and more moistnesse but neþelesse kende haþe ordeyned a purgacioun at certeyn tymes of bledynge to make her bodies clene and hole frome alle sikenesses and þei haue scuhe purgaciouns fro þe tyme of xij wynter of age in to the age of fifty wynter
msItem.explicit: 128v sotilte of the blood þat swetiþ þrowe smale poris of þe veynesse and so ffloweþ oute [.] Eiþere for þe blode is vndefied [...]
msItem.note: Treated as chapters 78 and 79 of the Compendium medicinae. Ends imperfectly.

supportDesc.support: Paper quires with parchment outer and inner leaves. Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 1r-126v: Scissors with a crescent moon.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corners of the rectos; however, from f. 37 a second foliator continues the sequence and corrects the first foliator, whose hand then only occurs every 10 leaves but miscounts and skips a leaf in quire 6. See f. 57r where the number 58 has been crossed out and corrected with 57. Folio [91a] is a stub of a missing leaf, which bears a small amount of text on the verso.

foliation.p: 17th-century numeration of the sections in the surgical treatise:
Written in brown ink in the outer upper corners of rectos and versos.

p.formula: 112-4 (1st-3rd and 12th leaves missing) 212 310 46-1 (4th leaf missing) 512-2 (1st and 12th leaves missing) 612-1 (1st leaf missing) 7-812 912-1 (12th leaf missing) 10-1212

signatures.p: Leaf signatures consisting of combinations of letters of the Roman alphabet and numerals: Quire 1: a; Quire 2: b; Quire 3: c; Quire 4: a; Quire 5: a; Quire 6: b; Quire 7: c; Quire 8: d; Quire 9: e; Quire 10: f; Quire 11: g; Quire 12: h: Single leaf (f. 128): j.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint but usually erased. Single columns. 35 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: The original texts in this manuscript were copied by a single hand writing in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: One large (5 lines) 'champ' initial: a gold initial in a frame with a blue and purple ground with spraywork in green and gold on f. 31r.
One large (4 lines) 'champ' initial: a gold initial in a frame with a blue and purple ground with spraywork in green, blue, and gold on f. 122r.
Large (2 lines) initials in blue in frames of red penwork decoration and with pen-flourishing in red ink throughout.
Small (1 or 2 lines) red initials used in the Somnia Danielis (ff. 26r-30v) and the table of contents (ff. 34v-35v).
Incipits and marginal headings rubricated in red ink.
Occasionally, long decorative flourishes in brown ink on descenders of letters on last lines (ff. 81v-82r).
Paraphs in blue or red ink.
Regula initials (1 line) highlighted in red ink.
Double virgula supensivas in red ink.

Added drawings in brown ink in margins throughout the manuscript: acorns and flower (f. 1r); knotwork motif (f. 2v); knotwork motif (f. 3r); knotwork motif (f. 7r); knotwork motif (f. 20v); flower (f. 22v); a hand holding a flower (f. 23r); a knotwork motif and two squares with geometrif figures (f. 29r); three-dimensional (?) shapes (f. 35r); a bird (f. 39r); a cadel design with a human face (f. 44r); cross lines pattern in plummet (f. 79v); a flower and leaves (f. 110r).
One large knotwork initial "O" outlined in dark ink in a large space that may have been left blank for a miniature on f. 3r.
A large initial "C" in the shape of a winged dragon both on f. 33r (fragmentary) and f. 34r; probably added in the late 16th or early 17th century.

note.p: Numerous additions on blank pages and in margins by late 15th- or early 16th-century hands, including titles for recipes (e.g. f. 56v: Stynkyng; f. 57r: Guta; f. 76r: defaute of apet; f. 108v: Stones; f. 115r: Siphatie; f. 117r: for the flower in women; f. 128v: fleynge of þe moder) or draft letters and verses: f. 2r (outer margin): Jhesus haue you in hys kepyng; f. 3r: Mendall f. 9r: ones be werie y put inne þere so þat the wonde be fillid full [...] f. 15r (upper margin): >Received the xth daye of 9 August [...] the xth yere; f. 27v: with many tribulan[...] hevene so [...]; f. 28r (outer margin): Mange hathe dessirid to know thers; f. 32v (uper margin: After my moste harty comended; f. 34r: thys boke is ?danyffaule[...] and yse stehy; f. 37r: Raff good andrewe spelt for me malone; f. 40r upper margin: I walked by pols [...]; f. 56r: Rex for the same mane that ys god; f. 67v: Rex et Regina Ano mundi f. 75r: Yf a bargen thow wyllt be p[..]tpe to; f. 83r: Roule youre hartes [...] f. 87v: Rex yf thou wist who; f. 102v: Howard by what; f. 103r: Of and in consideracioun of the summe of xli of good and lafull mone of England to be paid vnto the said margeret wheth f. 103r: This ys to warne all men what Jhon Com kise me [...] John Com kise; f. 127r: Robert Sippin ys a knave a lought a luber a Rascal a [...]; f. 128v: to tinke; f. 117r: and yf thow wist what; f. 117r: Whan the son shineth. Other more substantial inscriptions are listed as separate items under the list of contents in this catalogue record. Inscriptions that may refer to owners, readers or users of this manuscript are listed in the Provenance section.
17th-century enumeration of medical sections written in brown ink in the upper outer corners of both the rectos and versos of leaves between f 36r and f. 91v.
Modern collation numbers in pencil written in the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires 5-12 plus the single leaf (f. 128) at the end: '1'-'9'.

binding.p: 18th- or 19th-century half white vellum binding with grey paper sides and plain white paper pastedowns on the inner covers; flat spine with three paper labels with the printed classmark numbers: O, 9, 37.
Binding height: 295 mm; width: 200 mm; depth: 40 mm.

provenance.p: Mary Hogan (fl. 16th century) Hogan, Mary, fl. 16th century: her name and a monogram of her name inscribed on f. 29v (lower margin): Mary Hooggon [a second hand has attempted to copy her signature] and MH.
Anna Hogan (fl. 16th century) Hogan, Anna, fl. 16th century: her name inscribed on f. 30v: Anna Hoogoon [a second hand has attempted to copy her name]
Anthony (fl. 16th century) Anthony, fl. 16th century: his name inscribed on f. 34r: anthony.

Robert Crondal (fl. 16th century) Crondal, Robert, fl. 16th century: his full name inscribed on f. 42r; possibly also inscribed his first name on ff. 15r (Robert) [2x]; and 52r (Robart [2x]). The family name Crondal may be a locative, referring to the village of Crondall in Hampshire.
Thomas Johnson (fl. 16th century) Johnson, Thomas, fl. 16th century: his name inscribed on f. 52r: Thomas Johnsonne [2x].
?John ?Bareheasy (fl. 16th century) ?Bareheasy, ?John, fl. 16th century: his name inscribed on f. 52r: J ?Bareheasy

One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635/6-1702, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge. The manuscript is listed as no. 305 (see f. 1r) in the list of Gale's manuscripts in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).
One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father.

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, son of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark are printed on three (much worn) labels pasted onto the spine (O.9.37), and those of its current and previous classmarks are inscribed in the manuscript: inside of the front cover (O.9.37 in brown ink); f. 1r (G.20 [crossed out], O.4.47 [crossed out], and O.9.37 in brown ink). Its printed ex libris featuring its armorial coat of arms and name (Collegium S.S. et Individuae Trinitatis in Academia Cantabrigiensi) pasted in inner corner of the lower margin on f. 1r.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue, 4 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1900–1904), pp. 75-82; and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995), pp. 22-23.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
